Policy_Details: """During Phase I, we can gradually start to reopen economic and social activity. This will be a deliberate process, and is flexible to adapt to the situation. Some communities may be able to reopen at a faster rate, while others may need to continue restrictions to keep the virus from spreading. During Phase I, we should limit our activity and interactions and continue to maintain social distancing and practice good hygiene to protect our neighbors and ourselves.

Citizens who feel sick should stay home!
Continue to practice good hygiene, including:
Washing hands with soap and water, or using hand sanitizer, especially after touching frequently used items or surfaces;
Avoiding touching your face;
Sneezing or coughing into a tissue, or the inside of your elbow; and
Disinfecting frequently used items and surfaces as much as possible.
Avoid socializing in groups that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing (receptions, trade shows, etc.). When in public (parks, outdoor recreation spaces, shopping malls, etc.), individuals should maximize physical distance from others.
Minimize travel to the extent possible."""   Source information: https://governor.mo.gov/sites/gov/files/media/pdf/2020/04/Economic-Reopening-Phase-1.pdf

Policy_Details: All businesses and employers are encouraged to adopt and/or take the following actions: Businesses should encourage customers to wear FACE COVERINGS. Continue to encourage TELEWORK, whenever possible and feasible with business operations. If possible, have employees RETURN TO WORK IN PHASES. CLOSE COMMON AREAS where personnel are likely to congregate and interact, or enforce strict social distancing protocols. Follow guidance from the NEVADA LABOR COMMISSIONER regarding sick leave policies. Strongly consider SPECIAL ACCOMMODATIONS for employees who are members of a vulnerable population. Consider encouraging employees to do a SELF-ASSESSMENT each day in order to check if they have any COVID-19 type symptoms (fever, cough or shortness of breath). Remind employees to STAY HOME WHEN SICK, use cough and sneeze etiquette, and practice hand hygiene. Frequently perform enhanced ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANING of commonly touched surfaces. Social Distancing & Sanitation Practices in Businesses - All businesses should consider proactive measures to help protect staff and customers, including but not limited to: • Implementing separate operating hours for the elderly and vulnerable customers. • Designating with signage, tape or by other means, six feet of spacing for employees, customers, clients or members to maintain appropriate distance. • Having hand sanitizer, and sanitizing products, readily available for employees and customers. Policy_Details: Governor Carney announced Phase 2 of Delaware's reopening will begin June 15, 2020
INDIVIDUAL GUIDELINES
-Cloth coverings must be worn
-Non-household members must maximize social distancing
-All individuals in public (parks, outdoor recreation areas, shopping, etc) must social distance
-Indoor gathering limit: 50 people but social distance from non-household members
-Places operating at 30% occupancy under Phase 1 can move to 60% occupancy 
-Exercise facilities and personal care services (hair, tanning, tattoo, massage, nail, brow, spas) to remain at 30% occupancy
-Fully unenclosed outdoor gatherings of up to 250 people are permitted
-Leisure travel should be avoided but may resume under general guidance
-All vulnerable individuals should continue to shelter in place
BUSINESS GUIDELINES
-Common areas where people can congregate must remain closed

Policy_Details: New Mexico's stay at home restrictions were modified on April 30, with an extension of the state's stay-at-home order in place until May 15.
New Mexicans must remain home except for outings essential for health, safety and welfare, especially elderly and vulnerable individuals. If you must leave home, gatherings of more than five people remain prohibited and 6 feet of physical distance from others must be maintained.
Large retailers like big-box stores and grocery stores will continue operating at 20 percent capacity as determined by fire code.  
Other high-intensity contact services that must remain closed include indoor malls, massage and tattoo parlors, theaters, casinos.
WHAT WILL CHANGE BEGINNING MAY 16:
All retailers may operate according to COVID-Safe Practices (“CSPs”) at 25 percent fire code occupancy (a “retailer” is any business that sells goods directly to the ultimate consumer or end-users and does not include wholesalers or suppliers, not does it include entertainment venues such as movie theaters, concert halls, or amusement parks);
Non-essential businesses (other than retailers; such as office spaces, call centers) generally may operate according to CSPs at up to 25 percent of pre-crisis staffing levels. All employees should continue to work from home wherever possible;
   Source information: https://cv.nmhealth.org/2020/05/13/stay-at-home-order-extended/

Policy_Details: "All businesses and employers are encouraged to adopt and/or take the following

Policy_Details: New Mexico's stay at home restrictions were modified on April 30, with an extension of the state's stay-at-home order in place until May 15. New Mexicans must remain home except for outings essential for health, safety and welfare, especially elderly and vulnerable individuals. If you must leave home, gatherings of more than five people remain prohibited and 6 feet of physical distance from others must be maintained. Large retailers like big-box stores and grocery stores will continue operating at 20 percent capacity as determined by fire code. Locations and services where high-intensity contact is unavoidable – such as gyms, salons and dine-in service at restaurants and bars – will remain temporarily closed. Limited in-person operations for those types of businesses could be included in the next modification of the public health order, as soon as early June, depending on New Mexico’s rate of COVID-19 transmission, testing capacity and other gating criteria. Other high-intensity contact services that must remain closed include indoor malls, massage and tattoo parlors, theaters, casinos. 14-day quarantine order remains in place for out-of-state airport arrivals. Vacation rentals prohibited to out-of-state residents. Visits to long-term care and other congregate care facilities remain restricted. WHAT WILL CHANGE BEGINNING MAY 16: All retailers may operate according to COVID-Safe Practices (“CSPs”) at 25 percent fire code occupancy (a “retailer” is any business that sells goods directly to the ultimate consumer or end-users and does not include wholesalers or suppliers, not does it include entertainment venues such as movie theaters, concert halls, or amusement parks); Non-essential businesses (other than retailers; such as office spaces, call centers) generally may operate according to CSPs at up to 25 percent of pre-crisis staffing levels. All employees should continue to work from home wherever possible; Houses of worship may operate at 10 percent occupancy; Additional state parks and certain outdoor recreation guides with COVID-Safe Practices; Masks will be required of everyone in public places, with exceptions for eating, drinking and exercising and medical requirements.   Source information: https://cv.nmhealth.org/2020/05/13/stay-at-home-order-extended/

Policy_Details: Governor Polis released public health order revising Safer at Home, and in the Vast, Great Outdoors
-Private campgrounds may open and campground operators must regularly clean & disinfect areas
-Group facilities, pavilions, cabins, yurts remain closed
-Campsites must be 6 ft apart, only available by reservation 
-Limit visitors in campground offices to maintain such distancing 
PERSONAL RECREATION 
-Personal recreation (playgrounds, outdoors sports facilities) at a maximum of 25 people 
-Outdoor swimming pools open at 50% occupancy, no more than 50 people 
-Organized recreational youth/adult league sports can start with no more than 25 players outdoors or 10 players indoors, parents can attend youth sports but remain 6 ft apart from non-household members, spectators discouraged at adult sports & sports league must retain records of players in case of later outbreak
-Gyms, recreation centers, indoor pools open at 25% occupancy, not to exceed 50 people, restrooms and showers open but lockers are closed
-Competitive events (races, endurance events) permitted with 6 ft distancing and limit on group size
OUTDOOR RECREATION 
-Outdoor recreation is permitted with non-guided recreation groups no larger than 10 people
-Guide services for fishing, hunting, biking, horseback riding, canoeing, kayaking, stand up paddle boarding, ATV tours, climbing permitted with groups no more than 10 people
-River outfitters, rafting, Jeep tours in groups up to 2 households in a boat or groups of no more than 10 in Jeep
-Developed hot springs may operate following outdoor pool requirements
-Outdoor recreation activities at ski resorts if local public health agency has reviewed & approved resort's plans 
-Outdoor recreation activities not at ski resorts if local public health agency has reviewed & approved plans 
-Scenic trains if every local public health agency in each jurisdiction train operates reviews and approves train's plans 
-Trail and conservation crew no larger than 10    Source information: https://covid19.colorado.gov/covid-19-in-colorado/public-health-executive-orders-resource

Policy_Details: "During Phase I, we can gradually start to reopen economic and social activity. This will be a deliberate process, and is flexible to adapt to the situation. During Phase I, we should limit our activity and interactions and continue to maintain social distancing and practice good hygiene to protect our neighbors and ourselves. Citizens who feel sick should stay home! Continue to practice good hygiene, including: Washing hands with soap and water, or using hand sanitizer, especially after touching frequently used items or surfaces; Avoiding touching your face; Sneezing or coughing into a tissue, or the inside of your elbow; and Disinfecting frequently used items and surfaces as much as possible. Avoid socializing in groups that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing (receptions, trade shows, etc.). When in public (parks, outdoor recreation spaces, shopping malls, etc.), individuals should maximize physical distance from others. Minimize travel to the extent possible." Policy_Details: "All businesses and employers are encouraged to adopt and/or take the following

Policy_Details: Currently open: Grocery stores, pharmacies, banks and credit unions, and gas stations are all open.
Restaurants are open for take-out service only.
Stand alone retail operations are open provided they meet required safety and physical distancing guidelines. Indoor and outdoor malls are closed.
Local outdoor recreation activities are open, including many state parks.
Non-emergency medical care, dentist offices and veterinary care are open and operating, provided they meet required safety guidelines.
Local cultural, civic and faith gatherings are allowed for up to 25 people provided physical distancing can be in place.
Local social gatherings over 10 people are prohibited and those under 10 people must use physical distancing.
Personal care services such as salons and barbers, as well as gyms, are closed.
Child care is open under certain restrictions, with priority placements for children of health care workers, first responders, and frontline workers.
Public transit is open under certain restrictions, and must be sanitized often and enforce 3 feet of space between passengers.
Overnight camps are not permitted. Day camps are open with restrictions, including maximum stable groups of 10 or fewer children.
For summer school, limited in-person, small group instruction and/or summer programming is allowed, with certain restrictions.

Policy_Details: Governor Carney announced Phase 2 of Delaware's reopening will begin June 15, 2020
INDIVIDUAL GUIDELINES
-Cloth coverings must be worn
-Non-household members must maximize social distancing
-All individuals in public (parks, outdoor recreation areas, shopping, etc) must social distance
-Indoor gathering limit: 50 people but social distance from non-household members
-Places operating at 30% occupancy under Phase 1 can move to 60% occupancy 
-Exercise facilities and personal care services (hair, tanning, tattoo, massage, nail, brow, spas) to remain at 30% occupancy
-Fully unenclosed outdoor gatherings of up to 250 people are permitted
-Leisure travel should be avoided but may resume under general guidance
-All vulnerable individuals should continue to shelter in place
BUSINESS GUIDELINES
-Common areas where people can congregate must remain closed
-Employees/customers have responsibility to self-quarantine if they think they may be sick
-Teleworking is encouraged
-All surfaces touched by customers must be disinfected by EPA-approved disinfectant every 15 minutes to 2 hours 
-Employees required to go to work should perform daily health work 
-All employees must wash hands throughout the day and use hand sanitizer and social distance from other employees
-Businesses must make hand sanitizer available to employees and patrons (hand sanitizer must be 60% ethanol and 70% isopropanol 
-Downtime should be given between shifts and after closing for cleaning 
-Employees must post signs about how to stop spread of COVID-19, hand hygiene, and wear a face covering  Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2020/06/Delaware-Economic-Reopening-PHASE-2.pdf

Policy_Details: """During Phase I, we can gradually start to reopen economic and social activity. This will be a deliberate process, and is flexible to adapt to the situation. Some communities may be able to reopen at a faster rate, while others may need to continue restrictions to keep the virus from spreading. During Phase I, we should limit our activity and interactions and continue to maintain social distancing and practice good hygiene to protect our neighbors and ourselves.

Citizens who feel sick should stay home!
Continue to practice good hygiene, including:
Washing hands with soap and water, or using hand sanitizer, especially after touching frequently used items or surfaces;
Avoiding touching your face;
Sneezing or coughing into a tissue, or the inside of your elbow; and
Disinfecting frequently used items and surfaces as much as possible.
Avoid socializing in groups that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing (receptions, trade shows, etc.). When in public (parks, outdoor recreation spaces, shopping malls, etc.), individuals should maximize physical distance from others.
Minimize travel to the extent possible."""   Source information: https://governor.mo.gov/sites/gov/files/media/pdf/2020/04/Economic-Reopening-Phase-1.pdf

Policy_Details: "All businesses and employers are encouraged to adopt and/or take the following
actions:
Businesses should encourage customers to wear FACE COVERINGS.
Continue to encourage TELEWORK, whenever possible and feasible with business operations.
If possible, have employees RETURN TO WORK IN PHASES.
CLOSE COMMON AREAS where personnel are likely to congregate and interact, or enforce strict social
distancing protocols.
Follow guidance from the NEVADA LABOR COMMISSIONER regarding sick leave policies.
Strongly consider SPECIAL ACCOMMODATIONS for employees who are members of a vulnerable
population.
Consider encouraging employees to do a SELF-ASSESSMENT each day in order to check if they have
any COVID-19 type symptoms (fever, cough or shortness of breath).
Remind employees to STAY HOME WHEN SICK, use cough and sneeze etiquette, and practice hand
hygiene.
Frequently perform enhanced ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANING of commonly touched surfaces.
Social Distancing & Sanitation Practices in Businesses - All businesses should consider proactive
measures to help protect staff and customers, including but not limited to:
• Implementing separate operating hours for the elderly and vulnerable customers.
• Designating with signage, tape or by other means, six feet of spacing for employees, customers,
clients or members to maintain appropriate distance.
• Having hand sanitizer, and sanitizing products, readily available for employees and customers."   Source information: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-018.Phase-1-Reopening.5-7-20-1.pdf

Policy_Details: New Mexico's stay at home restrictions were modified on April 30, with an extension of the state's stay-at-home order in place until May 15. New Mexicans must remain home except for outings essential for health, safety and welfare, especially elderly and vulnerable individuals. If you must leave home, gatherings of more than five people remain prohibited and 6 feet of physical distance from others must be maintained. Large retailers like big-box stores and grocery stores will continue operating at 20 percent capacity as determined by fire code. Locations and services where high-intensity contact is unavoidable – such as gyms, salons and dine-in service at restaurants and bars – will remain temporarily closed. Limited in-person operations for those types of businesses could be included in the next modification of the public health order, as soon as early June, depending on New Mexico’s rate of COVID-19 transmission, testing capacity and other gating criteria. Other high-intensity contact services that must remain closed include indoor malls, massage and tattoo parlors, theaters, casinos. 14-day quarantine order remains in place for out-of-state airport arrivals. Vacation rentals prohibited to out-of-state residents. Visits to long-term care and other congregate care facilities remain restricted. WHAT WILL CHANGE BEGINNING MAY 16: All retailers may operate according to COVID-Safe Practices (“CSPs”) at 25 percent fire code occupancy (a “retailer” is any business that sells goods directly to the ultimate consumer or end-users and does not include wholesalers or suppliers, not does it include entertainment venues such as movie theaters, concert halls, or amusement parks); Non-essential businesses (other than retailers; such as office spaces, call centers) generally may operate according to CSPs at up to 25 percent of pre-crisis staffing levels. All employees should continue to work from home wherever possible; Houses of worship may operate at 10 percent occupancy; Additional state parks and certain outdoor recreation guides with COVID-Safe Practices; Masks will be required of everyone in public places, with exceptions for eating, drinking and exercising and medical requirements. Policy_Details: non-construction-related home installations (e.g. carpet installation, home theaters, security systems) ; auto dealers & wholesalers, browsing inside showroom ; libraries, browsing inside ; retail stores (incl. malls), browsing inside ; castio hotels & restaurants ; behind-the-wheel training/observation of student drivers ; occupational schools open to students completing degree/prerequisite for employment ; hotels, motels, inns, short-term lodgings open to guests ; personal services w/out close contact (photography, window washers, career coaching) ; close-contact personal services (massage therapy, nail salons, tattoo parlors, electrolysis studios) to open mid-way through Phase II ; personal training to open mid-way through Phase II ; restaurant takeout, delivery, outdoor seating (indoor seating midway through Phase II) ; flight schools ; beer gardens, breweries, wineries, distilleries if providing seated food service ; non-athletic instructional classes in arts, education, life skills for youths under age 18 in groups of fewer than 10 ; funeral homes ; warehouses/distribution centers ; outdoor historic sites ; outdoor recreational facilities (i.e. pools, playgrounds, spray decks, mini golf, go karts, batting cages, climbing walls) ; professional sports practice/training ; organized amateur sports (outdoor only for adults, indoor for supervised youth programs) ; recreational day camps ; golf facilities (incl. outdoor driving ranges) Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://www.mass.gov/doc/executive-order-preparing-for-phase-ii-reopening/download
